results.title: A meeting of ways
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Describes the process of organising a community art project for a newly-opened community centre in Melbourne called Ross House. This program records the joys, the frustrations, the tears, the highs and the lows in the making of community art.
results.description:

results.title: Old Songs in a New Land: A Piece of Jewish Australian ...
results.creator_credit: Judy Menczel, Barbara Mariotti and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Inspired by an exhibition of the same name held at Hyde Park Barracks, Sydney 1988 and organised by the Bicentennial Committee, NSW Jewish Board of Deputies, this video portrays the history of the Jews in Australia from those who arrived on the First Fleet to the Jewish immigrants from Russia of the present day. Interviews with representatives of the Jewish community highlight the differences which still exist within the community which yet retains a distinctively Jewish character.

results.title: Saturday school
results.creator_credit: Rick Cavaggion, Georgia Allan and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Ethnic language schools have been a part of Australia’s educational history since the 1850’s. However, until the advent of multiculturalism in the early 1970s, ethnic language schools were treated with disdain by the mainstream educational authorities who believed in assimilation programs for migrants rather than a continuing of cultural and linguistic ethnic traditions. In this video, the South Australian model for ethnic schools is investigated, including sources of financial assistance; the important work the schools do in maintaining respect for langauge and culture; and the role the schools now have in teaching new languages to children from English-speaking backgrounds.

results.title: Saigon Doctor
results.creator_credit: Georgia Allen, Kathryn Millard and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
A dramatised story of a young Vietnamese doctor who has come to Australia with his wife and child, only to find his medical qualifications are unrecognised here. He therefore enrols in a requalification course a long way from his family. As well as exploring the issue of recognition of overseas qualifications the video also focuses on the young man’s feelings of isolation, frustration, deprivation and development of a sense of community. As well as building on the social issues raised by the video, the accompanying Teacher’s notes also show how the video can be used in drama production.

results.title: The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey
results.creator_credit: Various, Reverse Angle Productions and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description: Seven documentary films individually directed with the director’s own viewpoint on the history of blues music. The series is presented by Martin Scorsese and is described in the trailer as “a musical journey to the roots of rock, soul and hip hop”. Directors include Mike Figgis, Clint Eastwood, Charles Burnett, Wim Wenders, Richard Pearce, Rober Kenner, and Marc Levin. — [319237] Red White and Blues (Figgis) — [319233] Piano Blues (Eastwood) — [319234] Warming by the Devil’s fire (Burnett) — [319235] The Soul of a man (Wenders) — [319236] The Road to Memphis (Pearce, Kenner) — [319238] Godfathers and sons (Levin) — [319239] Feel like going home (Scosese)
results.title_for_label: The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey
results.description: Seven documentary films individually directed with the director’s own viewpoint on the history of blues music. The series is presented by Martin Scorsese and is described in the trailer as “a musical journey to the roots of rock, soul and hip hop”. results.title: What's mad to you? Part 2. New approaches
results.creator_credit: Barbara A. Chobocky, Margaret Smith and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
A group of psychiatrists and counsellors who offer alternative kinds of psychiatric help talk about their methods. They all stress that the need for change has to come from the patients themselves and that any change is likely to be small and not likely to happen quickly. Some of their patients also talk about their treatment and we are shown brief glimpses of sessions between therapist and patient.
results.title_for_label: What’s mad to you? Part 2. New approaches
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barbara A. Chobocky, Margaret Smith and SBS-TV

results.title: What do you really do for a job? = [May Day]
results.creator_credit: Sally Ingleton, Philip Howe and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
The first of May is International Labour Day marking the struggle to achieve the eight hour working day. The Northern Territory is one of the few States still celebrating May 1st as a holiday. This program follows the preparations by community groups, trade unions and artistic directors, Neil Cameron and Jan McDonald, to revitalise the 1989 May Day celebrations in Darwin by creating a lively and colourful parade and festival where workers could have a good time and still prove unity is strength.
results.title_for_label: What do you really do for a job? = [May Day]
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sally Ingleton, Philip Howe and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service

results.title: Threads of Ireland
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
This program looks at the traditions and culture brought to Australia by the Irish Catholic convicts, and the way in which the Irish influence is still present in modern Australia. Explores the history of Australian writing, music and religion which have an Irish influence.

results.title: Godfathers and sons
results.creator_credit: Marc Levin, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey [DVD]”.
Part of Martin Scorsese’s “The Blues Collection”. When immigrants from Poland and African Americans migrating north from the oppression of the south came together, some magic was made through music - in particular, the formation of Chess Records in 1950 - initially created by two Jewish brothers who were inspired listening to gospel music at a local church. Marc Levin looks at the history of blues by talking to the son of the founder of Chess, Marshall Chess and his take on music and inter-racial relations at the time. Marshall’s psychodelic inspired project Electric Mud featuring Muddy Waters is a pivotal album in the influential sphere of Chuck D from hip-hop’s Public Enemy. Exploring his roots, Chuck D, and Marshall, take a tour of Chicago and re-form the Electric Mud Group to pay homage to the ‘roots’ of blues and add their own contemporary interpretation. Marshall’s life in music went beyond the recording industry and he worked in the 1960s for seven years as Company Manager for the Rolling Stones. The take up of the blues by young white musicians in the UK and the US in the 1960s is shown - the cycle of Godfathers influencing the Sons. Features archival performance footage and includes live concert footage of the Chicago Blues Festival and the legendary Koko Taylor at her club. Howlin’ Wolf, Bob Dylan, Willie Dixon, Muddy Waters, Pinetop Perkins, and Ike Turner are some of the artists featured.

results.title: Red, white and blues = Red, white & blues
results.creator_credit: Mike Figgis, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey [DVD]”.
Part of Martin Scorsese’s “The Blues Collection”, “Red, White & Blues” is directed by Mike Figgis with is his take on the influence of American blues music on musicians in the United Kingdom. A jam session recorded live in the studios at Abbey Road 2002 with some of the big names from the UK - Tom Jones, Jeff Beck, Lulu, and Van Morrison (to name a few) - provides an anchor point for the film and in between songs recorded at the session are interviews and music clips which make up this documentary. From the post-war years and a tradition of folk music and ‘skiffle’, the blues found a new audience and enthusiasts for the form flourished. Nightclubs featuring rhythm and blues bands became abundant; vinyl records were shared amongst friends and fellow musicians, spreading the blues influence until it exploded in the 1960s. Bands from the UK (such as The Rolling Stones and Cream) toured in America during this period whereupon names like Muddy Waters and B.B. King became household names in what otherwise may have been a lost art form in mainstream America. Some of the performers featured/interviewed include Booker T & the MGs, Big Bill Broonzy, Georgie Fame, Lonnie Donegan, The Beatles, Sister Rosetta Tharpe, Alexis Korner, John Mayall, Eric Clapton, Eric Burdon and Mick Fleetwood.
